6.a: Conversion going on to 3 & 4 family units

areaDesc.14: Old section. Reasonably well kept up. "D" beacuse of age.
The larger part of this area is outside the city limits.
Old downtown center. Mixed values. Age and obsolescence of structures.
Cheaply constructed laborers' cottages. Area is outside the city limits.
Nearer to a "B" rating than to a "D".
Labor commutes by automobile to and from Flint.
Cheap construction. Laborers' homes.
Comparatively new section of cheap construction. Laborers' homes. Outside the city.
Cheap laborers' cottages. Some as small as two rooms. Easternmost three streets are outside the city limits.
Cheap showy construction-- "Florida" style.
The Park and Country Club are a help. Ten or twelve houses in the entire neighborhood.

areaDesc.13: Slowly declining. Homes of the workers in the Fisher Body plant which is within walking distance.
The parks and open spaces are a help to this area

areaDesc.14: Area outside the city limits.
Very cheap and old construction.
Given "D" grading because of age. Many persons like the area because it is clsoe to the business center.

areaDesc.13: Will hold up. Pride of ownership.
areaDesc.14: Too close to “C” and “D” areas toward the west. East of Avon and just opposite the Burroughs Park, homes range in value above $12,000. South by east from the Park on Kennelworth and Ridgelawn, the values run $7,500 to $11,000 with one or two up to $25,000.
Good rental area. Close in to the center of town. Old section mixed as to values.

areaDesc.13: Will hold up. Factory executives--with pride of wonership.
areaDesc.14: In the western limits of this area, Maxine, Blanchard and Kensington Streets-- values range from $7,500 to $11,500.

areaDesc.13: Desirable for tenants-- close to town

areaDesc.14: Wide variation of values on unpaved streets. Homes built to order by construction company on owner's lots. Varying from bungalow to two-family types.

areaDesc.13: Pride of ownership displayed-- Will hold up
areaDesc.14: The Park helps the area.
Undesirables- aliens and negroes.
Cheap four-room frames; better along Court St. and Lapeer Road. A large part of this area is outside the city limits.
Nearer to a "B" rating than to a "D".

6.b: Frame, solid brick stone & brick veneer

areaDesc.14: On Miller Road the houses do not face the street. The change of grading at Miller Road is as abrupt as though there was a high brick wall along that street.

areaDesc.2: Rolling. The east end is known as "Knob Hill".
areaDesc.14: North of Miller Road—the western extremity to garden Street, the homes range from $3,500 to $7,500. East of Garden Street on Garden, Crescent and South Streets, the homes are worth upward of $12,000. South of Miller Road the values range from $7,500 to $12,000.
Old downtown center. various types of structures. The northernmost strip lying along Bluff ranges from $1,000 to $2,500.
Old downtown center. Mixed values. Age and obsolescence of structures.
Laborers home. Depend upon factory employment. Area is outside the city limits.
Area outside the city limits.

areaDesc.13: Workers homes. Depends upon work available.

areaDesc.2: Flat. From Detroit St. to Dupont, the area is called "Indian Village". West of Dupont- the "Highlands."
areaDesc.14: At the southern extreme of the area, Nolen to Thomas St. there are homes at above $12,000. From Nolen to Frank St. there are homes worth from $7500 to $10,000. Along the south side of Welch Avenue from Lavender St. to Dupont, there are homes of $7500 to $12,000 values. Between Welch and Stockdale, from Chevrolet to Detroit there are $8,000 to $10,000 homes. Along both sides of Hamilton St. Forest Hill St. to Detroit, there are $8,000 to 10,000 homes. Practically this entire area of 3,200 houses was built by a subsidiary of general Motors to house Company employees. The HOLC has 70 mortgages taken from the General Motors subsidiary. Information from R.W Cross Housing Division of General motors Corporation.
The nearer to Detroit Avenue the property, the more desirableit is for walking distance to work.

6.a: Singles, with a few 2 adn 4 family units

areaDesc.13: Old on Saginaw-- better toward Detroit Ave.

areaDesc.14: Walking distance from the Buick plant.

Immediately north of Area B-1 and as far up as Ridgeway Street, the homes have an average age of perhaps 16 years with a current range in value of $2,500 to $4,000. Decline will be slow if employment holds well at the Buick and Chevrolet factories.
Cheap construction with a few houses in about $4,000 class on Saginaw and Carpenter Road. This area is north of the City line.
Cheap construction. Laborers homes. Area outside the city limits.

areaDesc.13: A matter of continuing factory employment.

6.d: Fair- below Taylor St. rather good, north of Taylor St.

areaDesc.14: Above Stweart construction is cheap; sparsely settled.

5.a: Small business men and laboring class

areaDesc.14: Old section obsolete toward the south end. No uniformity to construction. Wide variation in values.
